http://edamontology.org/topic_0003.label: Experimental design and studies
http://edamontology.org/topic_0003.description: The design of an experiment intended to test a hypothesis, and describe or explain empirical data obtained under various experimental conditions.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3678.label: Animal study
http://edamontology.org/topic_3678.description: The design of an experiment involving non-human animals.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3391.label: Phenomics
http://edamontology.org/topic_3391.description: Phenomes, or the study of the change in phenotype (the physical and biochemical traits of organisms) in response to genetic and environmental factors.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0622.label: Population genomics
http://edamontology.org/topic_0622.description: Large-scale study (typically comparison) of DNA sequences of populations.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3361.label: Immunoprecipitation experiment
http://edamontology.org/topic_3361.description: Experimental techniques to purify a protein-DNA crosslinked complex.  Usually sequencing follows e.g. in the techniques ChIP-chip, ChIP-seq and MeDIP-seq.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3656.label: RNA immunoprecipitation
http://edamontology.org/topic_3656.description: An antibody-based technique used to map in vivo RNA-protein interactions.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3382.label: Tomography
http://edamontology.org/topic_3382.description: Imaging in sections (sectioning), through the use of a wave-generating device (tomograph) that generates an image (a tomogram).

http://edamontology.org/topic_3168.label: Metagenomic sequencing
http://edamontology.org/topic_3168.description: Approach which samples, in parallel, all genes in all organisms present in a given sample, e.g. to provide insight into biodiversity and function.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3344.label: Regenerative medicine
http://edamontology.org/topic_3344.description: Biomedical approaches to clinical interventions that involve the use of stem cells.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3386.label: Animal study
http://edamontology.org/topic_3386.description: The design of an experiment involving non-human animals.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3376.label: Regulatory affairs
http://edamontology.org/topic_3376.description: The protection of public health by controlling the safety and efficacy of products in areas including pharmaceuticals, veterinary medicine, medical devices, pesticides, agrochemicals, cosmetics, and complementary medicines.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3377.label: Pharmacovigilence
http://edamontology.org/topic_3377.description: The detection, assesment, understanding and prevention of adverse effects of medicines.|Pharmacovigilence concerns safety once a drug has gone to market.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3336.label: Compound libraries and screening
http://edamontology.org/topic_3336.description: Collections of chemicals, typically for use in high-throughput screening experiments.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3277.label: Clone library
http://edamontology.org/topic_3277.description: Collections of DNA, including both collections of cloned molecules, and populations of micro-organisms that store and propagate cloned DNA.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0202.label: Pharmacogenomics
http://edamontology.org/topic_0202.description: The influence of genotype on drug response, for example by correlating gene expression or single-nucleotide polymorphisms with drug efficacy or toxicity.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3318.label: Biophysics
http://edamontology.org/topic_3318.description: The use of physics to study biological system.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3316.label: Machine learning
http://edamontology.org/topic_3316.description: A topic concerning the application of artificial intelligence methods to algorithms, in order to create methods that can learn from data in order to generate an ouput, rather than relying on explicitly encoded information only.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3315.label: Pure mathematics
http://edamontology.org/topic_3315.description: The study of abstract mathematical concepts.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3314.label: Synthetic chemistry
http://edamontology.org/topic_3314.description: The use of chemistry to create new compounds.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3371.label: Chemical biology
http://edamontology.org/topic_3371.description: The use of synthetic chemistry to study and manipulate biological systems.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3336.label: Compound libraries and screening
http://edamontology.org/topic_3336.description: Collections of chemicals, typically for use in high-throughput screening experiments.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3307.label: Molecular genetics
http://edamontology.org/topic_3307.description: The structure and function of genes at a molecular level.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0199.label: DNA structural variation
http://edamontology.org/topic_0199.description: Variation in chromosome structure including microscopic and submicroscopic types of variation such as deletions, duplications, copy-number variants, insertions, inversions and translocations.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0114.label: Gene transcripts
http://edamontology.org/topic_0114.description: Transcription of DNA into RNA and features of a messenger RNA (mRNA) molecules including precursor RNA, primary (unprocessed) transcript and fully processed molecules.|This includes 5'untranslated region (5'UTR), coding sequences (CDS), exons, intervening sequences (intron) and 3'untranslated regions (3'UTR).|This includes regions or sites in a eukaryotic and eukaryotic viral RNA sequence which directs endonuclease cleavage or polyadenylation of an RNA transcript.  A polyA signal is required for endonuclease cleavage of an RNA transcript that is followed by polyadenylation. A polyA site is a site on an RNA transcript to which adenine residues will be added during post-transcriptional polyadenylation.|This includes Introns, and protein-coding regions including coding sequences (CDS), exons, translation initiation sites and open reading frames.  Also expressed sequence tag (EST) or complementary DNA (cDNA) sequences.|This includes coding sequences for a signal or transit peptide.  A signal peptide coding sequence encodes an N-terminal domain of a secreted protein, which is involved in attaching the polypeptide to a membrane leader sequence. A transit peptide coding sequence encodes an N-terminal domain of a nuclear-encoded organellar protein; which is involved in import of the protein into the organelle.

http://edamontology.org/topic_1775.label: Functional genomics
http://edamontology.org/topic_1775.description: The study of gene or protein functions and their interactions in totality in a given organism, tissue, cell etc.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0602.label: Protein interactions
http://edamontology.org/topic_0602.description: Protein-protein, protein-DNA/RNA and protein-ligand interactions, including analysis of known interactions and prediction of putative interactions.|This includes experimental (e.g. yeast two-hybrid) and computational analysis techniques.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0160.label: Nucleic acid sites, features and motifs

http://edamontology.org/topic_3511.label: DNA binding sites
http://edamontology.org/topic_3511.description: Nucleic acids binding to some other molecule.|This includes sites involved with DNA replication and recombination.  This includes binding sites for initiation of replication (origin of replication), regions where transfer is initiated during the conjugation or mobilisation (origin of transfer), starting sites for DNA duplication (origin of replication) and regions which are eliminated through any of kind of recombination.  Also nucleosome exclusion regions, i.e. specific patterns or regions which exclude nucleosomes (the basic structural units of eukaryotic chromatin which play a significant role in regulating gene expression).|This includes ribosome binding sites (Shine-Dalgarno sequence in prokaryotes), restriction enzyme recognition sites (restriction sites) etc.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0610.description: The ecology of microorganisms including their relationship with one another and their environment.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3068.label: Natural language processing
http://edamontology.org/topic_3068.description: The processing and analysis of natural language, such as scientific literature in English, in order to extract data and information, or to enable human-computer interaction.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0605.label: Data management
http://edamontology.org/topic_0605.description: The development and use of architectures, policies, practices and procedures for management of data.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3071.label: Data quality management
http://edamontology.org/topic_3071.description: The quality, integrity, and cleaning up of data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0004.label: Quantification
http://edamontology.org/operation_0004.description: Counting and measuring experimentally determined observations into quantities.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3799.label: RNA-Seq quantification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3799.description: Quantification of data arising from RNA-Seq high-throughput sequencing, typically the quantification of transcript abundances durnig transcriptome analysis in a gene expression study.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3630.label: MRM/SRM
http://edamontology.org/operation_3630.description: Quantification by Selected/multiple Reaction Monitoring workflow (XIC quantitation of precursor / fragment mass pair).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3635.label: Metabolic labeling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3635.description: Labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 or N-15 enriched grown medium or feed.|This includes N-15 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using N-15 enriched grown medium or feed) and C-13 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 enriched grown medium or feed).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3634.label: Ion counting
http://edamontology.org/operation_3634.description: Label-free quantification by integration of ion current (ion counting).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3760.label: Service invocation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3760.description: An operation supporting the calling (invocation) of other tools and services.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3465.label: Gene expression correlation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3465.description: Analyse the correlation patterns among genes across across a variety of experiments, microarray samples etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3438.label: Rarefaction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3438.description: The calculation of species richness for a number of individual samples, based on plots of the number of species as a function of the number of samples (rarefaction curves).

http://edamontology.org/operation_2238.label: Statistical modelling
http://edamontology.org/operation_2238.description: Construction of a statistical model, or a set of assumptions around some observed data, usually by describing a set of probability distributions which approximate the distribution of data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0262.label: Nucleic acid curvature calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0262.description: Calculate curvature and flexibility / stiffness of a nucleotide sequence.|This includes properties such as.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0456.label: Nucleic acid temperature profile plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0456.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA temperature profile.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0250.label: Protein hydropathy calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0250.description: Analyse the hydrophobic, hydrophilic or charge properties of a protein (from analysis of sequence or structural information).

http://edamontology.org/operation_2574.label: Protein crystallizability prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_2574.description: Predict crystallizability of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0400.label: Protein hydrogen exchange rate calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0400.description: Estimate hydrogen exchange rate of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0398.label: Protein fragment weight comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_0398.description: Calculate the molecular weight of a protein (or fragments) and compare it to another protein or reference data. Generally used for protein identification.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0249.label: Ramachandran plot calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0249.description: Calculate a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0248.label: Residue distance calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0248.description: Calculate contacts between residues, or between residues and other groups, in a protein structure, on the basis of distance calculations.|This includes identifying HET groups, which usually correspond to ligands, lipids, but might also (not consistently) include groups that are attached to amino acids. http://edamontology.org/operation_2950.label: Residue cluster calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2950.description: Calculate clusters of contacting residues in protein structures.|This includes for example clusters of hydrophobic or charged residues, or clusters of contacting residues which have a key structural or functional role.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0391.label: Protein contact map calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0391.description: Calculate a residue contact map (typically all-versus-all inter-residue contacts) for a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0236.label: k-mer counting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0236.description: Count k-mers (substrings of length k) in DNA sequence data.|k-mer counting is used in genome and transcriptome assembly, metagenomic sequencing, and for error correction of sequence reads.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3434.label: Sequence coordinate conversion
http://edamontology.org/operation_3434.description: Convert one set of sequence coordinates to another, e.g. convert coordinates of one assembly to another, cDNA to genomic, CDS to genomic, protein translation to genomic etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0233.label: DNA back-translation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0233.description: Back-translate a protein sequence into DNA.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3432.label: Document clustering
http://edamontology.org/operation_3432.description: Cluster (group) documents on the basis of their calculated similarity.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0291.label: Functional clustering
http://edamontology.org/operation_0291.description: Clustering of molecular sequences on the basis of their function, typically using information from an ontology of gene function, or some other measure of functional phenotype.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3429.label: Probabilistic data generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3429.description: Generate some data from a choosen probibalistic model, possibly to evaluate algorithms.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2928.label: Protein fold recognition
http://edamontology.org/operation_2928.description: Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.|Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0303.label: Protein threading

http://edamontology.org/operation_0295.label: Global structure alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0295.description: Globally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.|Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0292.label: Read mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_0292.description: Align short oligonucleotide sequences (reads) to a larger (genomic) sequence.|The purpose of read mapping is to identify the location of sequenced fragments within a reference genome and assumes that there is, in fact, at least local similarity between the fragment and reference sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3198.label: Split read mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_3198.description: A varient of oligonucleotide mapping where a read is mapped to two separate locations because of possible structural variation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0323.label: Phylogenetic tree reconstruction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0323.description: Reconstructing the inner node labels of a phylogenetic tree from its leafes.|Note that this is somewhat different from simply analysing an existing tree or constructing a completely new one.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0539.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (AI methods)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0539.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree by using artificial-intelligence methods, for example genetic algorithms.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0538.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (from polymorphism data)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0538.description: Phylogenetic tree construction from polymorphism data including microsatellites, RFLP (restriction fragment length polymorphisms), RAPD (random-amplified polymorphic DNA) and AFLP (amplified fragment length polymorphisms) data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0540.label: Phylogenetic species tree construction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0540.description: Construct a phylogenetic species tree, for example, from a genome-wide sequence comparison.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0314.description: Combine classical quantitative trait loci (QTL) analysis with gene expression profiling, for example, to describe describe cis- and trans-controlling elements for the expression of phenotype associated genes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0291.label: Functional clustering
http://edamontology.org/operation_0291.description: Clustering of molecular sequences on the basis of their function, typically using information from an ontology of gene function, or some other measure of functional phenotype.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0282.label: Haplotype mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_0282.description: Infer haplotypes, either alleles at multiple loci that are transmitted together on the same chromosome, or a set of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on a single chromatid that are statistically associated.|Haplotype inference can help in population genetic studies and the identification of complex disease genes, , and is typically based on aligned single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) fragments. Haplotype comparison is a useful way to characterize the genetic variation between individuals. An individual's haplotype describes which nucleotide base occurs at each position for a set of common SNPs. Tools might use combinatorial functions (for example parsimony) or a likelihood function or model with optimisation such as minimum error correction (MEC) model, expectation-maximisation algorithm (EM), genetic algorithm or Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0230.label: Probabilistic sequence generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0230.description: Generate sequences from some probabilistic model, e.g. a model that simulates evolution.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2514.label: de Novo sequencing
http://edamontology.org/operation_2514.description: Analytical process that derives a peptides amino acid sequence from its tandem mass spectrum (MS/MS) without the assistance of a sequence database.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2513.label: Base-calling
http://edamontology.org/operation_2513.description: Identify base (nucleobase) sequence from a fluorescence 'trace' data generated by an automated DNA sequencer.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2990.label: Single particle alignment and classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_2990.description: Compare (align and classify) multiple particle images from a micrograph in order to produce a representative image of the particle. |A micrograph can include particles in multiple different orientations and/or conformations. Particles are compared and organised into sets based on their similarity. Typically iterations of classification and alignment and are performed to optimise the final 3D EM map.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2996.label: Protein architecture recognition
http://edamontology.org/operation_2996.description: Identify the architecture of a protein structure.|Includes methods that try to suggest the most likely biological unit for a given protein X-ray crystal structure based on crystal symmetry and scoring of putative protein-protein interfaces.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2995.label: Taxonomic classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_2995.description: Classifiication (typically of molecular sequences) by assignment to some taxonomic hierarchy.

The input is typically a set of genes or other biological objects, possibly represented by their identifiers, and the output of the analysis is typically a ranked list of categories, each associated with a statistical metric of over-/under-representation within the studied data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3501.label: Chemical similarity enrichment
http://edamontology.org/operation_3501.description: Analyse a dataset with respect to concepts from an ontology of chemical structure, leveraging chemical similarity information.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3635.description: Labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 or N-15 enriched grown medium or feed.|This includes N-15 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using N-15 enriched grown medium or feed) and C-13 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 enriched grown medium or feed).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3634.label: Ion counting

http://edamontology.org/operation_3197.label: Collapsing methods
http://edamontology.org/operation_3197.description: A method whereby data on several variants are "collapsed" into a single covariate based on regions such as genes.|Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) analyse a genome-wide set of genetic variants in different individuals to see if any variant is associated with a trait. Traditional association techniques can lack the power to detect the significance of rare variants individually, or measure their compound effect (rare variant burden).  "Collapsing methods" were developed to overcome these problems.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0325.description: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to calculate distances between trees.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0323.description: Reconstructing the inner node labels of a phylogenetic tree from its leafes.|Note that this is somewhat different from simply analysing an existing tree or constructing a completely new one.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0539.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (AI methods)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0539.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree by using artificial-intelligence methods, for example genetic algorithms.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0282.description: Infer haplotypes, either alleles at multiple loci that are transmitted together on the same chromosome, or a set of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on a single chromatid that are statistically associated.|Haplotype inference can help in population genetic studies and the identification of complex disease genes, , and is typically based on aligned single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) fragments. An individual's haplotype describes which nucleotide base occurs at each position for a set of common SNPs. http://edamontology.org/operation_0474.description: Build a three-dimensional protein model based on known (for example homologs) structures.|The model might be of a whole, part or aspect of protein structure. http://edamontology.org/operation_0415.label: Peak calling
http://edamontology.org/operation_0415.description: Identify putative protein-binding regions in a genome sequence from analysis of Chip-sequencing data or ChIP-on-chip data.|Chip-sequencing combines chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) with massively parallel DNA sequencing to generate a set of reads, which are aligned to a genome sequence. http://edamontology.org/operation_0438.description: Identify matrix/scaffold attachment regions (MARs/SARs) in DNA sequences.|MAR/SAR sites often flank a gene or gene cluster and are found nearby cis-regulatory sequences. They might contribute to transcription regulation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0248.description: Calculate contacts between residues, or between residues and other groups, in a protein structure, on the basis of distance calculations.|This includes identifying HET groups, which usually correspond to ligands, lipids, but might also (not consistently) include groups that are attached to amino acids. It can also include calculation of symmetry contacts, i.e. a contact between two atoms in different asymmetric unit.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2950.description: Calculate clusters of contacting residues in protein structures.|This includes for example clusters of hydrophobic or charged residues, or clusters of contacting residues which have a key structural or functional role.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2409.description: Sort a set of files or data items according to some property.

http://edamontology.org/data_2024.label: Hanes Woolf plot
http://edamontology.org/data_2024.description: A plot based on the Michaelis Menten equation of enzyme kinetics plotting the ratio of the initial substrate concentration (S) against the reaction velocity (v).

http://edamontology.org/data_1534.label: Hopp and Woods plot
http://edamontology.org/data_1534.description: A Hopp and Woods plot of predicted antigenicity of a peptide or protein.

http://edamontology.org/data_2082.label: Gene order
http://edamontology.org/data_2082.description: Multiple gene identifiers in a specific order.|Such data are often used for genome rearrangement tools and phylogenetic tree labeling.

http://edamontology.org/data_2855.label: Structural distance matrix
http://edamontology.org/data_2855.description: Distances (values representing similarity) between a group of molecular structures.

http://edamontology.org/data_2854.label: Fingerprint
http://edamontology.org/data_2854.description: One or more fingerprints (sequence classifiers) as used in the PRINTS database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1501.label: Amino acid index (van der Waals radii)
http://edamontology.org/data_1501.description: Van der Waals radii of atoms for different amino acid residues.

http://edamontology.org/data_0892.label: 3D-1D scoring matrix
http://edamontology.org/data_0892.description: A matrix of 3D-1D scores reflecting the probability of amino acids to occur in different tertiary structural environments.

http://edamontology.org/data_0874.label: Comparison matrix (amino acid)
http://edamontology.org/data_0874.description: Matrix of integer or floating point numbers for amino acid comparison.

http://edamontology.org/data_2080.label: Sequence search results
http://edamontology.org/data_2080.description: A report of sequence hits and associated data from searching a database of sequences (for example a BLAST search). This will typically include a list of scores (often with statistical evaluation) and a set of alignments for the hits.|The score list includes the alignment score, percentage of the query sequence matched, length of the database sequence entry in this alignment, identifier of the database sequence entry, excerpt of the database sequence entry description etc.

http://edamontology.org/data_2048.label: Over-representation report
http://edamontology.org/data_2048.description: An informative report containing a ranked list of categories (usually ontology concepts), each associated with a statistical metric of over-/under-representation within the studied data.

http://edamontology.org/data_3753.label: GO-term enrichment report
http://edamontology.org/data_3753.description: An informative report containing a ranked list of Gene Ontology concepts, each associated with a p-value, concerning or derived from the analysis of e.g. a set of genes or proteins.

http://edamontology.org/data_3717.label: Isolation source
http://edamontology.org/data_3717.description: A report about any kind of isolation source of biological material e.g. blood, water, soil.

http://edamontology.org/data_3716.label: Biosafety classification
http://edamontology.org/data_3716.description: Information about the biosafety classification of an organism according to corresponding law.

http://edamontology.org/data_3707.label: Gamma diversity data
http://edamontology.org/data_3707.description: The total species diversity in a landscape.

http://edamontology.org/data_2955.label: Sequence image
http://edamontology.org/data_2955.description: Image of a molecular sequence, possibly with sequence features or properties shown.

http://edamontology.org/data_2969.label: Sequence trace image
http://edamontology.org/data_2969.description: Image of a sequence trace (nucleotide sequence versus probabilities of each of the 4 bases).

http://edamontology.org/data_1254.label: Sequence composition report
http://edamontology.org/data_1254.description: A report (typically a table) on character or word composition / frequency of a molecular sequence(s).

http://edamontology.org/data_1261.label: Nucleic acid density plot
http://edamontology.org/data_1261.description: Density plot (of base composition) for a nucleotide sequence.

http://edamontology.org/data_2762.label: Nucleic acid signature
http://edamontology.org/data_2762.description: An informative report about a specific or conserved nucleic acid sequence pattern.

http://edamontology.org/data_2530.label: Genome report
http://edamontology.org/data_2530.description: An informative report of general information concerning a genome as a whole.

http://edamontology.org/data_2337.label: Sample annotation
http://edamontology.org/data_2337.description: Annotation on a biological sample, for example experimental factors and their values.|This might include compound and dose in a dose response experiment.

http://edamontology.org/data_2085.label: Nucleic acid structure report
http://edamontology.org/data_2085.description: A report on regions within a nucleic acid sequence which form secondary or tertiary (3D) structures.

http://edamontology.org/data_1537.label: Protein geometry report
http://edamontology.org/data_1537.description: Geometry data for a protein structure, for example bond lengths, bond angles, torsion angles, chiralities, planaraties etc.

http://edamontology.org/data_2991.label: Ramachandran plot
http://edamontology.org/data_2991.description: Phi/psi angle data or a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/data_0906.label: Protein-ligand interaction report
http://edamontology.org/data_0906.description: An informative report on protein-ligand (small molecule) interaction(s).

http://edamontology.org/data_0962.label: Drug report
http://edamontology.org/data_0962.description: An informative report on a specific drug.

http://edamontology.org/data_1696.label: Drug structure relationship map
http://edamontology.org/data_1696.description: A report typically including a map (diagram) of drug structure relationships.

http://edamontology.org/data_2084.label: Gene family report
http://edamontology.org/data_2084.description: An informative report on a particular family of genes, typically a set of genes with similar sequence that originate from duplication of a common ancestor gene, or any other classification of nucleic acid sequences or structures that reflects gene structure.|This includes reports on on gene homologues between species.

http://edamontology.org/data_3148.label: RNA family report
http://edamontology.org/data_3148.description: An informative report on a specific RNA family or other group of classified RNA sequences.

synonyms: Nucleic acid features (gene and transcript structure)
http://edamontology.org/data_1276.label: Gene report
http://edamontology.org/data_1276.description: A report on predicted or actual gene structure, regions which make an RNA product and features such as promoters, coding regions, splice sites etc.|This includes any report on a particular locus or gene.  This might include the gene name, description, summary and so on. It can include details about the function of a gene, such as its encoded protein or a functional classification of the gene sequence along according to the encoded protein(s).

http://edamontology.org/data_0916.label: Gene transcript report
http://edamontology.org/data_0916.description: An informative report on features of a messenger RNA (mRNA) molecules including precursor RNA, primary (unprocessed) transcript and fully processed molecules. This includes reports on a specific gene transcript, clone or EST.|This includes 5'untranslated region (5'UTR), coding sequences (CDS), exons, intervening sequences (intron) and 3'untranslated regions (3'UTR).

http://edamontology.org/data_0920.label: Disease report
http://edamontology.org/data_0920.description: An informative report on a specific disease.|For example, an informative report on a specific tumor including nature and origin of the sample, anatomic site, organ or tissue, tumor type, including morphology and/or histologic type, and so on.

http://edamontology.org/data_0896.label: Protein structure report
http://edamontology.org/data_0896.description: Annotation about, or structural information derived from, one or more specific protein 3D structure(s) or structural domains.|This includes for example reports on the surface properties (shape, hydropathy, electrostatic patches etc) of a protein structure, protein flexibility or motion, and protein architecture (spatial arrangement of secondary structure).

http://edamontology.org/data_1537.label: Protein geometry report
http://edamontology.org/data_1537.description: Geometry data for a protein structure, for example bond lengths, bond angles, torsion angles, chiralities, planaraties etc.

http://edamontology.org/data_2991.label: Ramachandran plot
http://edamontology.org/data_2991.description: Phi/psi angle data or a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/data_0906.label: Protein-ligand interaction report
http://edamontology.org/data_0906.description: An informative report on protein-ligand (small molecule) interaction(s).

http://edamontology.org/data_0867.label: Sequence assembly report
http://edamontology.org/data_0867.description: An informative report about a DNA sequence assembly.|This might include an overall quality assement of the assembly and summary statistics including counts, average length and number of bases for reads, matches and non-matches, contigs, reads in pairs etc.

http://edamontology.org/data_2044.label: Nucleic acid sequence
http://edamontology.org/data_2044.description: One or more nucleic acid sequences, possibly with associated annotation.

http://edamontology.org/data_2976.label: Protein sequence (raw)
http://edamontology.org/data_2976.description: A raw protein sequence (string of characters).

http://edamontology.org/data_0849.label: Nucleic acid sequence record
http://edamontology.org/data_0849.description: A nucleic acid sequence and associated metadata.

http://edamontology.org/data_2019.label: Sequence coordinates
http://edamontology.org/data_2019.description: A position in a map (for example a genetic map), either a single position (point) or a region / interval.|This includes positions in genomes based on a reference sequence. A position may be specified for any mappable object, i.e. anything that may have positional information such as a physical position in a chromosome. Data might include sequence region name, strand, coordinate system name, assembly name, start position and end position.

http://edamontology.org/data_2012.label: Cytoband position
http://edamontology.org/data_2012.description: The position of a cytogenetic band in a genome.|Information might include start and end position in a chromosome sequence, chromosome identifier, name of band and so on.

http://edamontology.org/data_1274.label: Physical map
http://edamontology.org/data_1274.description: A map of DNA (linear or circular) annotated with physical features or landmarks such as restriction sites, cloned DNA fragments, genes or genetic markers, along with the physical distances between them.|Distance in a physical map is measured in base pairs. A physical map might be ordered relative to a reference map (typically a genetic map) in the process of genome sequencing.

http://edamontology.org/data_1280.label: Radiation hybrid map
http://edamontology.org/data_1280.description: A map showing distance between genetic markers estimated by radiation-induced breaks in a chromosome.|The radiation method can break very closely linked markers providing a more detailed map.  Most genetic markers and subsequences may be located to a defined map position and with a more precise estimates of distance than a linkage map.

http://edamontology.org/data_1283.label: Deletion map
http://edamontology.org/data_1283.description: A cytogenetic map showing chromosome banding patterns in mutant cell lines relative to the wild type.|A cytogenetic map is built from a set of mutant cell lines with sub-chromosomal deletions and a reference wild-type line ('genome deletion panel'). The panel is used to map markers onto the genome by comparing mutant to wild-type banding patterns. Markers are linked (occur in the same deleted region) if they share the same banding pattern (presence or absence) as the deletion panel.

http://edamontology.org/data_1279.label: Restriction map
http://edamontology.org/data_1279.description: Image of the restriction enzyme cleavage sites (restriction sites) in a nucleic acid sequence.

http://edamontology.org/data_1278.label: Haplotype map
http://edamontology.org/data_1278.description: A map of haplotypes in a genome or other sequence, describing common patterns of genetic variation.

http://edamontology.org/data_1916.label: Protein alignment
http://edamontology.org/data_1916.description: An alignment of protein sequences and/or structures.

http://edamontology.org/data_2366.label: Secondary structure alignment (RNA)
http://edamontology.org/data_2366.description: Alignment of the (1D representations of) secondary structure of two or more RNA molecules.

http://edamontology.org/data_0886.label: Structure alignment (nucleic acid)
http://edamontology.org/data_0886.description: Alignment (superimposition) of nucleic acid tertiary (3D) structures.

http://edamontology.org/data_0863.label: Sequence alignment (hybrid)
http://edamontology.org/data_0863.description: Alignment of multiple molecular sequences of different types.|Hybrid sequence alignments include for example genomic DNA to EST, cDNA or mRNA.

http://edamontology.org/data_1772.label: Localisation score
http://edamontology.org/data_1772.description: Score for localization of one or more post-translational modifications in peptide sequence measured by mass spectrometry.

http://edamontology.org/data_1394.label: Gap penalty
http://edamontology.org/data_1394.description: A penalty for introducing or extending a gap in an alignment.

http://edamontology.org/data_2137.label: Gap separation penalty
http://edamontology.org/data_2137.description: A penalty for gaps that are close together in an alignment.

http://edamontology.org/data_1398.label: Terminal gap extension penalty
http://edamontology.org/data_1398.description: A number defining the penalty for extending gaps at the termini of an alignment, either from the N/C terminal of protein or 5'/3' terminal of nucleotide sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_1397.label: Terminal gap opening penalty
http://edamontology.org/data_1397.description: A number defining the penalty for opening gaps at the termini of an alignment, either from the N/C terminal of protein or 5'/3' terminal of nucleotide sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_0951.label: P-value
http://edamontology.org/data_0951.description: The P-value is the probability of obtaining by random chance a result that is at least as extreme as an observed result, assuming a NULL hypothesis is true.|A z-value might be specified as a threshold for reporting hits from database searches.

http://edamontology.org/data_0888.label: Tanimoto similarity score
http://edamontology.org/data_0888.description: A measure of the similarity between two ligand fingerprints.|A ligand fingerprint is derived from ligand structural data from a Protein DataBank file. It reflects the elements or groups present or absent, covalent bonds and bond orders and the bonded environment in terms of SATIS codes and BLEEP atom types.

http://edamontology.org/data_0865.label: Sequence similarity
http://edamontology.org/data_0865.description: Sequence similarity is the similarity (expressed as a percentage) of two molecular sequences calculated from their alignment, a scoring matrix for scoring characters substitutions and penalties for gap insertion and extension.|Data Type is float probably.

http://edamontology.org/data_1413.label: Bit score
http://edamontology.org/data_1413.description: A score derived from the alignment of two sequences, which is then normalised with respect to the scoring system.|Bit scores are normalised with respect to the scoring system and therefore can be used to compare alignment scores from different searches.

http://edamontology.org/data_1255.label: Annotation track
http://edamontology.org/data_1255.description: Annotation of one particular positional feature on a biomolecular (typically genome) sequence, suitable for import and display in a genome browser.

synonyms: Nucleic acid features (gene and transcript structure)
http://edamontology.org/data_1276.label: Gene report
http://edamontology.org/data_1276.description: A report on predicted or actual gene structure, regions which make an RNA product and features such as promoters, coding regions, splice sites etc.|This includes any report on a particular locus or gene.  This might include the gene name, description, summary and so on. It can include details about the function of a gene, such as its encoded protein or a functional classification of the gene sequence along according to the encoded protein(s).

http://edamontology.org/data_0916.label: Gene transcript report
http://edamontology.org/data_0916.description: An informative report on features of a messenger RNA (mRNA) molecules including precursor RNA, primary (unprocessed) transcript and fully processed molecules. This includes reports on a specific gene transcript, clone or EST.|This includes 5'untranslated region (5'UTR), coding sequences (CDS), exons, intervening sequences (intron) and 3'untranslated regions (3'UTR).

http://edamontology.org/data_0968.label: UniProt keyword
http://edamontology.org/data_0968.description: A word or phrase that can appear in the keywords field (KW line) of entries from the UniProt database.

http://edamontology.org/data_0955.label: Genome index
http://edamontology.org/data_0955.description: An index of a genome sequence.|Many sequence alignment tasks involving many or very large sequences rely on a precomputed index of the sequence to accelerate the alignment.

http://edamontology.org/data_0950.label: Kinetic model
http://edamontology.org/data_0950.description: Mathematical model of a network, that contains biochemical kinetics.

http://edamontology.org/data_0914.label: Codon usage bias
http://edamontology.org/data_0914.description: A numerical measure of differences in the frequency of occurrence of synonymous codons in DNA sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_0883.label: 3D EM Mask
http://edamontology.org/data_0883.description: Annotation on a structural 3D EM Map from electron microscopy. This might include one or several locations in the map of the known features of a particular macromolecule.

http://edamontology.org/data_1463.label: Toxin structure
http://edamontology.org/data_1463.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for the (3D) structure of a toxin.

http://edamontology.org/data_1460.label: Protein structural motif
http://edamontology.org/data_1460.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for a protein (3D) structural motif; any group of contiguous or non-contiguous amino acid residues but typically those forming a feature with a structural or functional role.

http://edamontology.org/data_1459.label: RNA structure
http://edamontology.org/data_1459.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for an RNA tertiary (3D) structure.

http://edamontology.org/data_1465.label: tRNA structure
http://edamontology.org/data_1465.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for a tRNA tertiary (3D) structure, including tmRNA, snoRNAs etc.

http://edamontology.org/data_0860.label: Sequence profile
http://edamontology.org/data_0860.description: Some type of statistical model representing a (typically multiple) sequence alignment.

http://edamontology.org/data_1354.label: Position-specific scoring matrix
http://edamontology.org/data_1354.description: A simple matrix of numbers, where each value (or column of values) is derived derived from analysis of the corresponding position in a sequence alignment.

http://edamontology.org/data_2854.label: Fingerprint
http://edamontology.org/data_2854.description: One or more fingerprints (sequence classifiers) as used in the PRINTS database.

http://edamontology.org/data_0850.label: Sequence cluster
http://edamontology.org/data_0850.description: A set of sequences that have been clustered or otherwise classified as belonging to a group including (typically) sequence cluster information.|The cluster might include sequences identifiers, short descriptions, alignment and summary information.

http://edamontology.org/data_1235.label: Sequence cluster (nucleic acid)
http://edamontology.org/data_1235.description: A cluster of nucleotide sequences.|The sequences are typically related, for example a family of sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_1234.label: Sequence cluster (nucleic acid)
http://edamontology.org/data_1234.description: A cluster of nucleotide sequences.|The sequences are typically related, for example a family of sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_1233.label: Peptide molecular weight hits
http://edamontology.org/data_1233.description: A report on peptide fragments of certain molecular weight(s) in one or more protein sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_0842.label: Identifier (hybrid)
http://edamontology.org/data_0842.description: An identifier that is re-used for data objects of fundamentally different types (typically served from a single database).|This branch provides an alternative organisation of the concepts nested under 'Accession' and 'Name'. All concepts under here are already included under 'Accession' or 'Name'.

http://edamontology.org/data_2109.label: MGI accession
http://edamontology.org/data_2109.description: Identifier of an object from the MGI database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2917.label: ConsensusPathDB entity name
http://edamontology.org/data_2917.description: Name of a physical entity from the ConsensusPathDB database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2649.label: Drug ID (PharmGKB)
http://edamontology.org/data_2649.description: Identifier of a drug from the pharmacogenetics and pharmacogenomics knowledge base (PharmGKB).

http://edamontology.org/data_2639.label: PubChem bioassay ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2639.description: Identifier of an assay from the PubChem database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2632.label: Locus ID (SGD)
http://edamontology.org/data_2632.description: Identifier for loci from SGD (Saccharomyces Genome Database).

http://edamontology.org/data_2610.label: Ensembl gene tree ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2610.description: Unique identifier for a gene tree from the Ensembl database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2387.label: TAIR accession (protein)
http://edamontology.org/data_2387.description: Identifier of a protein sequence from the TAIR database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1037.label: TAIR accession (At gene)
http://edamontology.org/data_1037.description: Identifier of an Arabidopsis thaliana gene from the TAIR database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2367.label: ASTD ID (tss)
http://edamontology.org/data_2367.description: Identifier of a transcription start site from the ASTD database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2113.label: WormBase wormpep ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2113.description: Protein identifier used by WormBase database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2104.label: Enzyme ID (BioCyc)
http://edamontology.org/data_2104.description: Identifier of an enzyme from the BioCyc enzymes database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1154.label: KEGG Glycan ID
http://edamontology.org/data_1154.description: Unique identifier of a glycan ligand from the KEGG GLYCAN database (a subset of KEGG LIGAND).

http://edamontology.org/data_1089.label: FlyBase secondary identifier
http://edamontology.org/data_1089.description: Secondary identifier of an object from the FlyBase database.|Secondary identifier are used to handle entries that were merged with or split from other entries in the database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2099.label: Sequencing metadata name
http://edamontology.org/data_2099.description: Data concerning a sequencing experiment, that may be specified as an input to some tool.

http://edamontology.org/data_3732.label: Run number
http://edamontology.org/data_3732.description: A number corresponding to the number of an analysis performed by a sequencing machine.  For example, if it's the 13th analysis, the run is 13.

http://edamontology.org/data_2909.label: KEGG organism code
http://edamontology.org/data_2909.description: A three-letter code used in the KEGG databases to uniquely identify organisms.

http://edamontology.org/data_1868.label: Family name
http://edamontology.org/data_1868.description: The name of a family of organism.

http://edamontology.org/data_1046.label: Cell line name
http://edamontology.org/data_1046.description: The name of a cell line.

http://edamontology.org/data_2316.label: Cell line name (assonant)
http://edamontology.org/data_2316.description: The name of a cell line.

http://edamontology.org/data_2299.label: Gene symbol
http://edamontology.org/data_2299.description: The short name of a gene; a single word that does not contain white space characters. It is typically derived from the gene name.

http://edamontology.org/data_2253.label: MIRIAM data type name
http://edamontology.org/data_2253.description: The name of a data type from the MIRIAM database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1163.label: MIRIAM data type synonymous name
http://edamontology.org/data_1163.description: A synonymous name of a data type from the MIRIAM database.|A synonymous name for a MIRIAM data type taken from a controlled vocabulary.

http://edamontology.org/data_2154.label: UniProt ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2154.description: An identifier of a polypeptide in the UniProt database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2129.label: OBO file format name
http://edamontology.org/data_2129.description: Name of an OBO file format such as OBO-XML, plain and so on.

http://edamontology.org/data_1757.label: PDB atom name
http://edamontology.org/data_1757.description: Identifier (a string) of a specific atom from a PDB file for a molecular structure.

http://edamontology.org/data_1131.label: SMART domain name
http://edamontology.org/data_1131.description: Name of a domain from the SMART database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1050.label: File base name
http://edamontology.org/data_1050.description: The base name of a file.|A file base name is the file name stripped of its directory specification and extension.

http://edamontology.org/data_1009.label: Kinase name
http://edamontology.org/data_1009.description: The name of a kinase protein.

http://edamontology.org/data_0987.label: Chromosome name (BioCyc)
http://edamontology.org/data_0987.description: Name of a chromosome as used in the BioCyc database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2091.label: Disease identifier
http://edamontology.org/data_2091.description: Identifier of an entry from a database of disease.

http://edamontology.org/data_1150.label: Orpha number
http://edamontology.org/data_1150.description: An identifier of a disease from the Orpha database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2911.label: AraC-XylS ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2911.description: Identifier of a transcription factor from the AraC-XylS database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2910.label: Protein family ID (PANTHER)
http://edamontology.org/data_2910.description: Accession number of an entry (family) from the PANTHER database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1133.label: InterPro secondary accession
http://edamontology.org/data_1133.description: Secondary accession number of an InterPro entry.

http://edamontology.org/data_2908.label: Strain accession
http://edamontology.org/data_2908.description: Identifier of a strain of an organism variant, typically a plant, virus or bacterium.

http://edamontology.org/data_2912.label: CCAP strain number
http://edamontology.org/data_2912.description: The number of a strain of algae and protozoa from the CCAP database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2785.label: DPVweb ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2785.description: A unique identifier for a virus from the DPVweb database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2903.label: NCBI genome accession
http://edamontology.org/data_2903.description: A unique identifier of a whole genome assigned by the NCBI.

http://edamontology.org/data_2902.label: MIRIAM URI
http://edamontology.org/data_2902.description: The URI (URL or URN) of a data entity from the MIRIAM database.|A MIRIAM URI consists of the URI of the MIRIAM data type (PubMed, UniProt etc) followed by the identifier of an element of that data type, for example PMID for a publication or an accession number for a GO term.

http://edamontology.org/data_2901.label: Protein accession
http://edamontology.org/data_2901.description: Accession of a protein deposited in a database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2907.label: Protein ID (EMBL/GenBank/DDBJ)
http://edamontology.org/data_2907.description: EMBL/GENBANK/DDBJ coding feature protein identifier, issued by International collaborators.|This qualifier consists of a stable ID portion (3+5 format with 3 position letters and 5 numbers) plus a version number after the decimal point. When the protein sequence encoded by the CDS changes, only the version number of the /protein_id value is incremented; the stable part of the /protein_id remains unchanged and as a result will permanently be associated with a given protein; this qualifier is valid only on CDS features which translate into a valid protein.
